MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Card Guidelines.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Health
Qst.Quest: if he will issue guidelines to the health boards in relation to medical cards that would provide that all persons living at home with their parents who are on reduced rate unemployment assistance would qualify automatically for the medical card in the same way that persons on unemployment benefit automatically qualify.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Under the Health Act, 1970 medical cards are issued to persons who, in the opinion of the Chief Executive Officer of the appropriate health board are unable, without undue hardship, to provide general practitioner services for themselves and their dependants.

MainHeading.P: The Chief Executive Officers draw up guidelines in relation to income limits and to assessment criteria: however, these guidelines are not statutorily binding and a person who would not qualify on the basis of the guidelines may still be awarded a medical card if the Chief Executive Officer considers that the person's medical needs or other circumstances would justify this. Persons aged between 16 and 25 years who are dependants of a person who is not a medical card holder are not normally entitled to a medical card except where they have an entitlement under EC regulations or where they are in receipt of a Disabled Person's Maintenance Allowance. The decision on whether or not a person is regarded as a dependant or as being financially independent is made by the Chief Executive Officer of the health board on the basis of the circumstances of the individual case.

I should stress that the position, as outlined above, applies equally to persons on unemployment assistance (whether at full or reduced rate) and to persons on unemployment benefit, and that there is no automatic right to a medical card in either case.

It is open to all persons to apply to the Chief Executive Officer of the appropriate health board for health services if they are unable to provide these services for themselves or their dependants without hardship. I am satisfied that health boards give sympathetic consideration to such applications when the circumstances warrant it.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Day Care Services for Disabled.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Health
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the Irish Wheelchair Association has had to discontinue day centre services to persons with a disability aged over 65; and if he will hold negotiations with the voluntary and statutory agencies in an effort to restore this service.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: As a result of the sudden withdrawal last year of a FÁS Teamwork scheme, the Irish Wheelchair Association was forced to discontinue its day care services at Clontarf for those aged 65 and over. Following discussions between the Irish Wheelchair Association and the Eastern Health Board, the health board examined the needs of each person aged over 65 and every one of them was offered some alternative service such as home care attendant service or attendance at other day centres or day clubs. These arrangements have now been put in place. Currently, as persons attending the Irish Wheelchair Association day centre approach 65 years they are assessed by the public health nurse with a view to providing the most appropriate alternative service.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Responsibility for Disabled.

Qst.askee: Minister for Health
Qst.Quest: if he has received submissions on, or if he intends to transfer responsibility for services to people with a disability to another Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The Programme for a Partnership Government recognises the importance of facilitating people with a disability to express their full citizenship and gives a commitment to eliminating inequality for all groups in society who have suffered from disability or disadvantage.

The Minister for Equality and Law Reform has responsibility for seeing that equality becomes a reality through institutional, administrative and legal reform. Traditionally lead responsibility for persons with a disability has been the responsibility of the Minister for Health including the provision of health services.
Discussions as to the relative responsibilities of the two Departments are ongoing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Summer Schools.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: the assistance, if any, which is available from her Department or the European Commission to students who wish to pursue studies in summer schools while on vacation from their normal studies; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Under the terms of Cultural Agreements between Ireland and various other countries summer school scholarships are awarded by countries to Irish students as follows: Belgium, 2; France, 4; Holland, 1; Germany, 2; Italy, 10; Spain, 10.

MainHeading.P: The courses are usually of one months duration. Applications are invited by the Department of Education through public advertisement. Scholarship holders get a fixed amount from the host country towards the cost of registration fees and accommodation. The Department reciprocates by taking students from above countries for summer courses in this country.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish Sailing Olympic Development Plan.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that, due to a lack of State funding, the Irish Sailing Development team initiative has not prospered; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: An application to my Department from the Irish Sailing Association for funding for its Olympic Development plan is at present being considered in the context of the 1993 allocations of grants to sporting organisations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Overcrowding in County Tipperary School.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, she has to deal with the enormous overcrowding problem in a school (details supplied) in County Tipperary; if she will meet a deputation of the school authorities so that they may outline the extent of the problem; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: In July 1992, my Department conveyed to the school authorities approval of a grant and authorisation to invite tenders for additional accommodation in the form of two prefabricated classrooms with associated toilet facilities to meet anticipated short and medium term needs. As an alternative, an equivalent grant was offered should the school authorities choose to provide a more permanent structure.

MainHeading.P: These classrooms have yet to be provided. Alternative proposals have now been received from the school authorities and are under consideration and a response will be made as soon as possible.
In the circumstances, I feel that receiving a deputation would not be useful at this time.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Health and Safety Standards.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: the code, if any, which exists for setting out minimum health and safety standards in primary schools; if this code is legally binding; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The most recent legislation in regard to health and safety standards is the Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act, 1989. The fundamental aim of this Act is the prevention of accidents and ill health at the place of work.

Employers are required to identify the hazards and assess the risks in the place of work and to draw up a written safety statement setting out the arrangements in place to safeguard safety and health in the work place.
The management authorities of schools with the co-operation of their staff have responsibility for implementation of the provisions of the Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act, 1989.

In order to increase awareness of the provisions of the 1989 Act and in order to standardise safety statements, as far as possible, my Department is presently engaged in drafting a circular for issue to school authorities to assist them in preparing such statements.
The Health and Safety Authority have prepared explanatory leaflets to assist employers with regard to the provisions of the Act and to help in drafting safety statements.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Qualification for Inservice Training.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if she will allow unqualified, but experienced, primary teachers who give invaluable service as substitutes to partake in inservice training courses; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: In-service courses for teachers conducted under the aegis of my Department or through grant-aid from my Department are intended to serve qualified teachers only.

In addition to these courses, my Department each year approves certain inservice courses conducted by external bodies under established criteria. The course details and content are firstly submitted to the Department for approval by the various organisations who wish to provide such courses.

The question of who attends these latter courses is a matter for the organising bodies. It is made clear to the organisers, however, that optimum benefit may not be derived by participants if the attendance at a course exceeds 50.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teacher Correspondence/Outreach Courses.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: the correspondence or outreach courses for teachers training which are available here or in the UK which are recognised by her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: In order to obtain full recognition as a primary school teacher in Ireland applicants must have completed satisfactorily an approved primary teacher training course.

The only primary teacher training courses run in this country which are recognised by my Department are the Bachelor of Education degree courses which are provided in the Colleges of Education for primary teachers; at present these are all three-year full-time courses.

Teachers holding qualifications obtained abroad and wishing to establish whether they would be eligible for recognition are required to submit full particulars of the course completed and of their qualification to my Department.

MainHeading.P: My Department does not hold a composite list of acceptable courses. Each application is assessed on an individual basis and in the case of applicants from EC countries in accordance with the provisions of Directive 89/48/EEC.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Grant Application.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if she will review the application by a person (details supplied) in Dublin 3 to avail of a higher education grant in view of the circumstances of this family.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Dublin Corporation is statutorily entrusted with the administration of the higher education grants scheme in this case, and I understand that the corporation has notified the person in question that he has been deemed ineligible for a grant on the basis that family reckonable income exceeded the prescribed income limit.
I understand that neither Dublin Corporation nor my Department has received any appeal in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Funding for Additional Classrooms.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if it is proposed to provide funding for the construction of four new classrooms at St. Attracta's amalgamated national school in Ballaghaderreen, County Roscommon; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that this amalgamation took place last September and has since had to operate on a split campus and, that at the time of the agreement of the amalgamation, this funding to provide new classrooms was promised.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that the former boys and girls school in Balaghaderreen amalgamated with effect from last September and is operating on a split campus. My Department is examining the situation with a view to determining the accommodation needs of the school. The next step would be to begin the planning process. After that stage the question of the funding of an extension would be considered in the light of the availability of finance and having regard to other commitments and priorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Technology Grant.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if, in relation to St. Vincent's Secondary School, Glasnevin, and previous parliamentary questions on the request for a grant for the new technology extension, she will give details of other schools which are seeking a retrospective grant and the amount of resources involved in each case; the schools which were placed on the pilot list for technology facilities; the number of schools on the list that have progressed with the facilities; the number that have received grants or have been refused; and the position with the grant application for £40,000 for the provision of hardware and furnishing for the technology room.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A fundamental requirement of the secondary schools building grant scheme is that to qualify for captial grant assistance from my Department in respect of any development the prior written approval of the Department must be obtained for that development. This requirement was not complied with by St. Vincent's Secondary School, Glasnevin in respect of the technology extension provided at the school. My Department has no funds available for the payment of what is in effect a retrospective grant.

A total of 173 schools, including St. Vincent's applied for and were paid the standard grant of £5,000 each for the purpose of assisting the introduction of junior technology within the existing resources available to them.

With regard to the request for a grant of £40,000 for the provision of hardware and furnishings at St. Vincent's the position remains as stated in reply to Question No. 128 from Deputy Gregory on 17 February last.
